If we are the government, and the government's money belongs to the government, why shouldn't the government use its money to help the poor?
This is the most fucked logic I've ever heard. The government does not create wealth or value. It creates currency to denote a certain amount of value. This is why making new currency makes all the currency less valuable - it's not creating new wealth.
The government issues currency to rationalize the economy and make a standard, unified way of trading value, rather than a barter system.
The government creates small slips of paper which we mutually agree to recognize as symbolizing a certain amount of value. (That value is decided by market prices, by the way, not the government.)
The government does not create the value which I possess, which those slips of paper represent. While you're right that the government "creates" currency, the government has no right to take the value which I created and own for itself.
If we are the government, and the government's money belongs to the government, why shouldn't the government use its money to help the poor?
Because taxation is theft, and it's not really charitable to take everyone else's money and give it away. (Besides the point that welfare does not really help the poor in most cases.)
Charity is self-sacrifice. It is not self-sacrificial or charitable to insist that *everyone else* give money to the corporation which has a monopoly on power for it to then redistribute. It *is* charitable to give your own money and time, and if you support charity, you should do so - but you shouldn't force everyone else to do the same.

Not only that, but there is a clear correlation between strong socialized care for the elderly and people having less kids. Less kids means less workers down the line to pay into social security, and thus the strain will become harder over time as a smaller workforce takes care of the generation preceding them. Social security is the opposite of self-sustaining - that's why even liberals are talking about means testing and raising the retirement age.

...Do you not understand debates? I'm showing you how your logic is shit.
1. Oliver Cromwell was a revolutionary republican against the monarchy. Practically The definition of progressive.
2. Eisenhower was a progressive Republican who expanded the government and was covertly supportive of the left, including the USSR.
3. The Soviet Union was a left-wing country. Stalin was commonly called "the leader of progressive humanity" and when members of the Progressive Party went to Russia they said, "We have seen the future and it works."
4. Puritans were progressives against the establishment Church of England. They were generally pacifists and supported strong government.
5. Of course the French Revolution were progressive. They founded a republic in the name of popular sovereignty and equality. The French Revolution was the ultimate progressive revolution, which began a tide that swept away the ancient order of Europe. Many of the revolutionaries were early socialists, like Proudhon.
If you think those groups are not progressive, you either have no knowledge of history, no historical context, or no understanding of progressivism.
